prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Ability of judge

para.paratext: The Panel undoubtedly considers the ability and reputation of a judge in determining whether to assign complex, multidistrict litigation to him or her. This factor is, however, rarely even alluded to in Panel decisions and even less frequently raised in briefs and arguments before the Panel. In some decisions, however, the Panel does note the ability of the transferee judge to accomplish the task at hand.[1]

In the early days of the Panel's operation the Panel was likely to transfer cases to judges who had handled major antitrust cases or who had participated in the Judicial Conference's Coordinating Committee for Multiple Litigation for the United States Courts.[2] Although the Panel does not seem especially likely to transfer cases to its own members, it has done so on occasion.[3] The Panel has often transferred cases, however, to former members of the Panel. In one case, it expressly identified former Panel membership, as well as leadership roles in various federal court committees as a reason for selecting Chief Judge Sam Pointer as a transferee judge.[4] Similarly, the Panel may look specifically to prior experience as a transferee judge in MDL proceedings.[5] In other cases, the Panel may refer more generally to the judge's experience and ability.[6]

The ability of judges is a difficult, if not perilous, subject for attorneys to raise. The Panel has not shown any particular receptiveness to arguments of counsel in this area. In one case a party argued that the general expertise of the judges of the District of Columbia warranted selection of that district over other potential transferee courts. The Panel found this argument “wholly without merit.”[7] This last notwithstanding, it is easier to raise the positive ability of a particular judge rather than the lack of ability of another potential judge. Both judges may be known to the Panel and mention of this factor would be barely necessary. It is possible that specific aspects of a judge's qualifications to serve might not be known to the Panel, and in that case information from the parties may be very helpful to the Panel's deliberations.

Another argument that is unlikely to carry a lot of weight with the Panel is one that the proposed transferee judge is biased, based on prior rulings. Because the Panel has recognized experience in handling related litigation is specifically an important qualifying factor, the fact that that litigation involved an outcome (i.e., an outcome one party was not happy with) cannot be a disqualifying fact. In one recent decision the Panel observed:

In opposing centralization in the District of Maryland, Tyson contends that assignment of this docket to Judge Bennett may give rise to a perception of unfairness, in that, in [the prior case] the judge issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting Tyson from continuing the aforementioned marketing practices. We specifically reject this contention. The mere fact that a judge has issued a prior ruling unfavorable to a particular party involved in Section 1407 proceedings provides no basis, without more, for disqualifying that judge from consideration for assignment of an MDL docket involving the same or similar issues. See Liteky v. United States, 510 U.S. 540, 555, 114 S.Ct. 1147, 127 L.Ed.2d 474 (1994) (“[O]pinions formed by [a] judge on the basis of facts introduced or events occurring in the course of the current proceedings, or of prior proceedings, do not constitute a basis for a bias or partiality motion unless they display a deep-seated favoritism or antagonism that would make fair judgment impossible.”).[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
